snippet: An extensive federal examination of banks’ foreclosure practices found that managers ignored widespread errors after the 2008 housing market collapse.
abstract: Housing and Urban Development Dept study of banks' foreclosure practices, which have caused a national uproar and prompted a $25 billion settlement between the banks and the government, finds that managers at major banks ignored widespread errors after the 2008 housing market collapse; banks face stiff penalties and intense public scrutiny if they fail to live up to the standards of the settlement.

byline.original: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ and J. B. SILVER-GREENBERG

lead_paragraph: An extensive federal examination of banks’ foreclosure practices found that managers ignored widespread errors after the 2008 housing market collapse.

headline.seo: Federal Report Cites Bank Officials in Foreclosure Surge
headline.main: Bank Officials Cited in Churn of Foreclosures
headline.print_headline: Bank Officials Cited in Churn Of Foreclosures
